required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Ultrasound Findings of Finger, Wrist and Knee Joints in Mucopolysaccharidosis
clinical_study.official_title: Ultrasound Findings of Finger, Wrist and Knee Joints in Mucopolysaccharidosis

brief_summary.textblock: Hardly any imaging studies specifically addressing the articular and periarticular structures in MPS patients are available at this point. The investigators propose to do for the first time a pilot study using musculoskeletal ultrasound in patients with various types of MPS.

primary_outcome.description: The primary objective is to determine whether patients with various types of MPS and at various stages of the disease exhibit abnormalities of the finger, wrist and knee joints as assessed by grey scale and Power Doppler ultrasonography.

secondary_outcome.description: To determine the optimal ultrasound scanning technique for MPS patients given the potentially advanced joint contractures
To determine whether there are ultrasound findings indicative of synovitis or tenosynovitis

secondary_outcome.measure: Differences between MPS I and IV
secondary_outcome.description: To determine whether differences exist between MPS I and MPS IV
To determine whether differences exist between patients with or without Enzyme Replacement Therapy (ERT) or Bone Marrow Transplants

secondary_outcome.measure: Differences between severe and attenuated phenotypes
secondary_outcome.description: To determine whether differences exist between severe and attenuated phenotypes

study_pop.textblock: Patients with MPS I and IV

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria
- Diagnosis of Mucopolysaccharidosis
- Ability to collaborate with the ultrasound assessment
- Written informed consent from parents and patients over 14 years of age, assent from children 7 to 14 years
Exclusion Criteria
- Inability to collaborate with the ultrasound assessment
- Acute trauma to a joint that will be assessed in the 3 months preceding the study
- Coexistence of other pathology that is known to affect the respective joints
